title: 113_hr3357
content: The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in various programs. This includes Head Start Programs, state-funded prekindergarten programs, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschools. Grants are authorized to be awarded to States by the Secretary of Education, in collaboration with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, for the implementation of specified activities. Each State seeking a grant under the "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" must submit an application to the Secretary of Education with details of their early childhood professional development system, including collaboration with relevant organizations, designation of a grant program administrator, and an oversight structure. The State's system for early childhood professional development must include an oversight structure, professional standards, career advancement opportunities, coordination with higher education institutions, articulation agreements, accessibility for working learners, and support for adult learners from diverse backgrounds. The State's system for early childhood professional development should include support for adult learners from diverse backgrounds, use of workforce data to assess needs, and financing over time. The State should use funds for early childhood professional development, including support for adult learners from diverse backgrounds, workforce data assessment, and financing over time. The State receiving a grant under this Act must use funds for scholarships, support for preschool teachers pursuing a degree in early childhood education, increasing compensation for teachers progressing towards a degree, and providing professional development opportunities. The program aims to offer professional development opportunities for preschool teachers and teacher assistants in an early childhood education program. This includes addressing all areas of child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence for working with diverse children and families. The Act requires grant funds to supplement, not replace, existing federal, state, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their fiscal effort for supported activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
